Applies to file:
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/README.md

This was a deliberate omission because it's dangerous but we need it for Travis automation. If documented, it should be accompanied with an appropriate warning since this is an irreversible action and with the option, there is no confirmation of which db is being wiped.
Interesting as this was taught as mainstream usage for developers...

What does this mean? It's not a document features and is used in exactly one place `tools/travis/build.sh`:

```
> grep -r dropit openwhisk
openwhisk/tools/db/createImmortalDBs.sh:if [[ "$1" != "--dropit" ]]; then
openwhisk/tools/travis/build.sh:./tools/db/createImmortalDBs.sh --dropit
```

It is in the readme.md as described above... the createImmortalDBs.sh is not just invoked in travis its mainstream instructions for developers installing running openwhisk in their local setup/env....

section : Initialize datastore containing authorization keys
tools/db/createImmortalDBs.sh 

During our team education sessions we were shown that we could use --dropit to avoid the manual intervention.

You're conflating `createImmortalDBs.sh` and the option to drop automatically. The former is documented, obviously, as it is a required step. The latter is not. It is special. Don't use it or rather if you're going to use, be very careful and sure of what it's doing.
Fixed by #407.
on the contrary, since being shown it, I use it several times a day (it seems) using the ephemeral CouchDB...
Closing for now, but its a lovely shortcut that clearly is used by devs.
FYI There are new instructions coming for couchdb that will make the repeated db init for couch no longer necessary.
Issue #?

i think this is a potentially interesting future item, but don't see it as a short-term item -- the implementation can become very complex, and would therefore prefer to first harden more basic scenarios.
i'd suggest to prioritize the event source higher than the action
Yes, sure.

Thanks for making the change.

I notice you have merge commits. You should use git fetch and git rebase rather than a git pull. This will allow a fast forward "merge" which preserves our linear git history. Also please squash your commits.
Sorry, please ignore this request.
Anyway, thank you rabbah, I'll use the command you recommended and take caution next time.
@markusthoemmes: the path is still for now relative. For reuse purpose, an absolute path in openwhisk is better.
@lehoanganh pls add issue # to this PR

Actually,  there is an argument not to reuse, in that each could be viewed as an optional plug-in.  If we indeed move to a framework design for datastores (and we can granularize the install/build process to take in parameters to declare the specific DB plug-in you want) then it would be good for each configuration/setup/init to be independent of one another.

It might be interesting to think about this in terms of draining the system. I.e. you send the invoker a `SIGTERM` signal, but it continues to finish the work it already has and exits afterwards, taking it ContainerPool with it.

@mrutkows: cloudant is also based on couchdb. The initdb step (multiple rest calls against db) is exactly same in both cases: cloudant and couchdb, so that the initdb step of couch should reuse cloudant. Otherwise, we have in both places same code.

If we have _another db_ e.g. cassandra, the initdb step for such another db should be different of course. (different ports, different endpoints, etc)

Yes, I know they are effectively the same datastore, and in fact one init file actually includes/references the other.  Despite having the same lineage, from an external users point-of-view, they are still separate entities and should not be cross-dependent in any of their install/config files IMO.  While reviewing the files in ansible subtree, this was actually a note I made last week to question why there is a cross-dependency as this would not be viewed favorably from an open perspective (or from the plug-in argument raised above).
you're rite. In order to use couch, one doesn't have to import cloudant role. we have had also this though before. but for now, we still don't have a better idea. But we keep it in mind.
Ouch. Doc is outdated, `http` is fine. In fact, this is what the default scripts use.

The plan is to do this after we can actually restart the invoker (kafka back pressure and activation count reset).  As it is, the cleanup here won't let you reclaim the machine anyhow.  Also, note that the invoker does clean up leftover stuff upon startup.

This one will be implemented once we have a stable go CLI in tools/go-cli/ released and tested. Right now the focus is to replace the current python cli with go cli in the same repo and do a clean swap.
For contrast https://github.com/docker/docker 1370 contributors, one repo, includes docs and cli.
closing as duplicate of #20.

When splitting existing repos into smaller, specialized ones, I found the following command to be really helpful:

`git filter-branch --prune-empty --tree-filter 'rm -rf <folders that don't belong in new repo>' HEAD`

If you start with an existing repo, and run this command and replace `<folders that don't belong in new repo>` with the list of folders which do not belong in the new specialized repo, you will be left with all the original commits/history for just the folders you want in the new repo. This pruned repo can then be pushed to your new URL.

For reference: https://www.git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Rewriting-History#The-Nuclear-Option:-filter-branch
Currently it prints the Dividers with no content, maybe we can put a count or a message that tells user run this command to copy/clone your first action. myhello
ideally we just add `-i`, `--insecure` option to not verify SSL certificate of API endpoint.

Doing it in the CLI is of course doable but the better place to do this and enforce it is in the controller.

First stage will be a setup guide for scalastyle in eclipse + choosing a guide. We'll need to tweak the guide to our needs before we finally enforce it on a build level.

After starting with a fresh docker-machine, I was able to run through the instructions.
Some comments:
- will there be some sugaring around these commands? surely we won't be typing these all the time.
- the deployment appears to be ok but it's not obvious that the catalog was installed. (this is perhaps just going to require some mental retraining.)
- some example for how to teardown and restart only a single component (e.g., ~~controller~~ or invoker)
  (for controller, this worked `ansible-playbook -i environments/mac controller.yml -e mode=clean` but doing the same with invoker tore down the entire deployment.)
- what's the equivalent of `ant deployDatabase` to wipe the transient tables
- ~~and to re-install the catalog?~~ (`ansible-playbook -i environments/mac postdeploy.yml` will do)

I like the idea of having full control when I'm running vagrant locally and be able to set some environment variables that CLI can take and pass debug flags.

I guess it will instruct the system to run a docker container, configured with nodejs with debug port open, where I can use node-inspector
and leave the docker warm and unlimited time to run the action.

I can open a debugger node-inspector or vscode that contects to the node process executing the action

when I call the action a second time the debugger brakes on the brake point.

I offer/suggest the following patch:

```
diff --git a/tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh b/tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh
index 01cfc99..5e1b90c 100755
--- a/tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh
+++ b/tools/macos/tweak-dockermachine.sh
@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 # > docker-machine create whisk --driver virtualbox

 # Set this to the name of the docker-machine VM.
-MACHINE_NAME=whisk
+MACHINE_NAME=${1:-whisk}

 # Disable TLS.
 docker-machine ssh $MACHINE_NAME "echo DOCKER_TLS=no |sudo tee -a /var/lib/boot2docker/profile > /dev/null"
@@ -22,17 +22,6 @@ docker-machine ssh $MACHINE_NAME "sudo chmod +x /var/lib/boot2docker/bootsync.sh

 rm -f bootsync.sh

-
-# Set routes on host.
-# If you notice the route forwarding is immediately deleted after this script
-# runs (you can check by running 'route monitor') then shut down your networking
-# (turn off wifi and disconnet all networking cables), wait a few secs and try
-# again; you should see the route stick and now you can reenable networking.
-MACHINE_VM_IP=$(docker-machine ip $MACHINE_NAME)
-sudo route -n -q delete 172.17.0.0/16
-sudo route -n -q add 172.17.0.0/16 $MACHINE_VM_IP
-netstat -nr |grep 172\.17
-
 # Install prereqs
 docker-machine ssh $MACHINE_NAME "sudo /var/lib/boot2docker/bootsync.sh > /dev/null"

@@ -41,9 +30,6 @@ docker-machine ssh $MACHINE_NAME "sudo /etc/init.d/docker restart"

 # Env variables to set.
 # Note, the user CAN NOT do eval $(docker-machine env whisk) because of a bug in docker-machine that assumes TLS even if not enabled
+MACHINE_VM_IP=$(docker-machine ip $MACHINE_NAME)
 echo Run the following:
 echo "  " export DOCKER_HOST="tcp://$MACHINE_VM_IP:4243"
-
-
-
-
```

Because it's a problem an user hit using the CLI

After reading closely I think this one it's an user error of not escaping the single quote in shell or cmd

I think there nothing the CLI can do to fix it but we can discuss here how to improve it

Brainstorm:
Passing JSON in terminal for simple things works fine but for complex strings it's not that good, what I did in another project I did a CLI was to have a flag in the CLI   to pass a JSON file containing the a json object with the information that the user would pass in terminal instead so you can pass the params as args or as a file input

@rabbah what's your opinion based on your docker reference?
That we should not split components long term and have everything in one repo. 

I'm not trying to disagree or agree, just want to hear your opinion and proposal. 

There are big successful open source projects that keep things in one repo and there are others that split them into different repos. 

This issue is to discuss pro and cons, short term and long term. What to split and what not to split. Or not to split anything l, etc... 

That's why I made it an Epic

Short term if we split the docs I think I want to leave a submodule in its place short term to make it easier to find the specific docs that match the code. 

and also for someone lurking into github can click on the docs folder and go the matching version of the docs 

Feedback is welcome

I would generalize this issue then to have better support for sending JSON - eg you cannot now send a top level json as in `wsk action invoke /whisk.system/samples/greeting '{"name":"..."}'`. Would be nice to also have the ability to send json from file.
Yep I agree more generic way to send json in CLI I just need help from someone deciphering original bug report
@csantanapr Yes, thank you.

> that an activation record in cloudant represents a trigger and not an action.

in whisk terminology, an activation results from the invocation of an action. why would an activation record represent a trigger? are we maybe overloading the term activation with multiple semantics?
yes, we should discuss the terminology, especially pertaining to user-visible terms.
current proposal on terminology:   an activation can refer to an action, a trigger, or a rule.
Is this fixed?

Introducing another term to refer to an activation of a trigger and/or a rule is unnecessary. Generally an activation of a trigger is the "firing" of a trigger. And an activation of a rule is the matching a trigger to a rule, causing an action to be invoked. Just as we equate "invoke" with activating an action, we can equate "fire" of a trigger with an activation of the trigger and possibly a rule.

The causality of activations chains can also be tracked and I expect this will be helpful in the future - one can build a graph of the activations with edge representing activation causality.

We currently show activations of triggers, rules and actions in `wsk activation poll` and `wsk activation list`. What we are missing is the "type" annotation on the activation and adding this will make it clear which kind of activation occurred.

that is fine with me as a baseline, but two items i think need to be refined:
- so far, all our collateral has been referring to an activation being equal to an invocation of an action. the rule & trigger flavor has never been discussed.
- we'll have to often talk about activations in the 'action invocation' sense. using the term 'action activation' seems very clunky, we should look for a short version here (so far that has been activation, but that is now overloaded)

Intuition tells me activation will (has) quite often mean (meant) action activation and having to qualify it is not necessary. Introducing another term to disambiguate widens the vocabulary unnecessarily when, where necessary, one can qualify the type of activation as needed. For example, `wsk activation poll` can show the type - surely if we referred to activations of different types by different names, you would not use the same CLI command, for example, since that would certainly then be confusing.

Anecdotal evidence also suggests that users have quite often figured this out on their own: bug reports we've received that talk about missing activations (of actions) have shown users are not confused. They will report for example that they see the activation of the trigger and rule but not the action.

i think we need to consider that using 'activation' for various flavors implies a degree of commonality across action/rule/trigger activations which is not necessarily the case. eg an action activation has a duration, begin and end time, which trigger & rule activations do not have. so need to be careful to not confuse people about commonality of attributes which is not there in reality.

The commonality is real today - they all have `begin` and `end` times, done via the same API verb `POST` (Trigger and Action) and all accessibly by the same API endpoint (`activations` collection). They even share the same implementation details to the extent possible in the controller. It is the case for triggers and rules that their activations are considered _instantaneous_ hence `start = end`. The part we are missing is the ability to _filter_ the activations elegantly and with convenience.
we might be filling out these fields, but in reality it's hard to see a case where start != end time and where duration != 0.
a trigger and rules activation is just a moment in time, while an action activation always takes time.

> but in reality it's hard to see a case where start != end time and where duration != 0.
> a trigger and rules activation is just a moment in time, while an action activation always takes time.

We agree then, don't we?

That is, if/when `start = end` (true for triggers/rules) then `duration = 0`. I'll concede that duration equal to zero is not the same as undefined but I am not convinced the distinction is important in this context.

In any case the proposed solution in the first comment is to make the trigger activation a point in time rather than one that has a duration. So I think the distinction you want to make is about naming an activation with a duration differently from an activation which is instantaneous.

The common parts of an activation are the fully qualified name, the point in time when it occurred, the subject causing the activation. The remaining properties can be factored into type specific schemas.
@rabbah please handle the merge
the mount still remains but it is set to UTC. since the image itself has UTC as default timezone, I'd propose we remove the mount as well. Any objections?

re `wsk action init` -- would it make sense to generalize this one, such that not only a hard-coded code template is used for creating the action, but rather that the user can select which code template should be used (from a catalog of public actions) ? a hello action could be the default if nothing is selected. thinking this through...should the command the be rather sth like `wsk action copy` vs init?

besides that, i think this would need a _convenient_ command for listing all public actions (not sure we have that today).

re `wsk action push` -- would this cover both `wsk action create` and `wsk action update` (ie make both of them obsolete) ?

this design has some analogy to git which I like.
on the `init` part I think there could be two use-cases of creation:
- init (in the sense of `git init`of a new repo. that would make a new action with only skeleton code)
- fork (in the sense `git clone` of an existing repo. that would make a local copy of a public action)

we could call the latter one e.g. `wsk clone`

the "cloning" of stuff would not even have to be limited to actions. I can imagine forking entire namespaces into my own one to get a whole hierarchy of actions, rules and triggers if they were flagged "public". need to discuss how that overlaps with the package concept, though.

It appears to me, that this and #443 are basically the same thing. Is there the possibility to deduplicate? Could we just return the "credentials" object and get the values we need directly in the test?
See #440 for a comment on deduplication. Are we creating specialized methods for every service that includes VCAP? These seem to be applicable for PushNotifications only?
in the context of your example, a `wsk action clone` would just create a copy of a given action. there could also be an `wsk package clone`, but i'd consider that to be out of scope for this issue.
An alternative is for one method that accepts a vararg String... Which is the map properties to add and return. I think this leads to least duplication?

@rabbah fixed the cleanup of invoker. now removes only invoker and action containers. also updated README.md with more examples and help. pls review.

The intention when you delete the feed is to stop the trigger from firing, that is why the trigger is deleted even if the life cycle manager fails.

Your point is valid about having to delete it manually, we should make it easier to retry deleting the feed when it fails.
should we add an additional flag to enforce deleting the trigger whenever the feed fails ?

@rabbah regarding your question on an equivalent of `ant deployDatabase`:

```
ansible-playbook -i <env> predeploy.yml
```

does the same thing.

> re wsk action init -- would it make sense to generalize this one, such that not only a hard-coded code template is used for creating the action, but rather that the user can select which code template should be used (from a catalog of public actions) ?

Yes I agree templates are always good entry point to see a demo/tutorial, and the author just provide a template. Usually the easiest would be url like a git url or ID in an openwhisk package registry/catalog
Like `wsk init --template https://github.com/csantanapr/openwhisk-demo1.git` or `wsk init --template ow-twilio-demo`

if the starting code is already inside the system then I would use `wsk clone namespace1/package1 or wsk clone namespace1/package1/entity1`

> we could call the latter one e.g. wsk clone

Yes I like both terms don't know which one to decide `clone` or `fork`. I think `clone` makes more sense since it's just I want a copy, no intention to do SCM and contribute back.
Assigning to Jason as per request from Billy.

Just to be clear (at a high level for now, don't worry about details}:

 'wsk clone/init/fork' should be equivalent to a sequence of 2 commands along the lines of 'wsk action get; wsk action create'
